properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Genoa River.

MINOR FLOODING EASING IN THE GENOA RIVER

Minor flooding is easing along the Genoa River. Flooding has eased along the Cann River.

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Friday, rainfall totals of 50-120 mm were recorded across the Cann, Genoa and Bemm River catchments. Further showers are forecast in East Gippsland during the remainder of Friday and into the weekend.

Genoa River:

Minor flooding is occurring along the Genoa River.

The Genoa River at The Gorge peaked at 3.12 metres around 04:00 pm Thursday 30 November with moderate flooding. The river level is currently at 2.30 metres and falling, with minor flooding. The Genoa River at The Gorge is likely to fall below the minor flood level (2.20 m) late Friday morning. Renewed rises are possible due to forecast rainfall over the weekend.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 02/12/2023 11:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Latrobe River.

  • Minor flooding is likely to develop at Rosedale from late Friday morning. River levels are likely to peak near the minor flood level at Thoms Bridge Friday evening. Rainfall since Wednesday morning across the Latrobe River catchment has resulted in river level rises.  Further rainfall is forecast for the remainder of Friday and Saturday. This situation is being closely monitored, and warnings will be updated as necessary. 

Latrobe River Yallourn to Traralgon Creek: 
  • Minor flooding is likely along the Latrobe River Yallourn to Traralgon Creek. The Latrobe River at Thoms Bridge is currently at 3.01 metres and rising below the minor flood level (4.00 m). The Latrobe River at Thoms Bridge is likely to peak near the minor flood level Friday evening. Further river level rises above the minor flood level may occur over the weekend with the forecast rainfall.

Latrobe River downstream of Traralgon:
  • Minor flooding is likely along the Latrobe River downstream of Traralgon. The Latrobe River at Rosedale (Main Stream) is currently at 3.84 metres and rising slowly below the minor flood level (4.00 m). The Latrobe River at Rosedale (Main Stream) is likely to exceed the minor flood level (4.00 m) late Friday morning. Further small river level rises are possible.

  • This is an update, replacing the Advice message issued at 12:22 PM.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Three Chain Road Cowwarr closed between Neilsons Road and Traralgon Maffra Road due to flooding
  • Riverview Road, Tinamba closed due to flooding
  • Traralgon-Maffra Road closed between Sale-Heyfeild Road and Commercial Road due to flooding.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 02/12/2023 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Flood Watch is being issued for the Wonnangatta River.

MODERATE FLOODING OCCURRING AT BAIRNSDALE FRIDAY AFTERNOON

MINOR FLOODING CONTINUING AT GLENALADALE

Rainfall since Wednesday morning across the Mitchell River catchment has resulted in river level rises and areas of flooding. Further rainfall is forecast for the remainder of Friday and into the weekend.

Renewed river level rises may occur over the weekend with the forecast rainfall

Wonnangatta River:

Minor flooding peaked along the Wonnangatta River during Friday morning and is currently falling. Renewed rises are possible with the forecast rain

This Advice replaces the Advice issued at 1.06pm on Friday 1st December. 
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do:
  • Decide what you and your family will do if flooding impacts you. For information on how to prepare go to www.ses.vic.gov.au/get-ready/floodsafe.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
Impacts in your area: 
  • Areas around rivers and streams may be flooded.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • For more information on road closures go to traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
  • Parks, hiking tracks and campgrounds are closed due to flooding. To find out more go to www.parkweb.vic.gov.au/safety/flood-affected-parks.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 02/12/2023 01:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Thomson River to Cowwarr Weir.

MAJOR FLOODING STEADY AT WANDOCKA

MODERATE FLOODING LIKELY AT SALE OVERNIGHT FRIDAY INTO SATURDAY

MODERATE FLOODING EASING AT COWWARR WEIR

Rainfall during the week across the Thomson River catchment has resulted in some strong river level rises. Further rainfall is forecast across the Thomson River catchment for the remainder of Friday and into the weekend which may cause renewed river level rises.

The situation is being closely monitored, and warnings will be updated as necessary

Thomson River to Cowwarr Weir:

Minor flooding is occurring along the Thomson River to Cowwarr Weir.

The Thomson River at Cooper Ck is currently at 2.07 metres and falling, below the minor flood level (2.30 m). The Thomson River at Cooper Ck is likely to remain below the minor flood level (2.30 m) during Saturday, with further renewed rises possible from late Saturday with forecast rainfall.

The Thomson River U/S Cowwarr Weir is currently at 4.28 metres and falling, with minor flooding. The Thomson River U/S Cowwarr Weir may fall below the minor flood level (3.70 m) overnight Friday into Saturday, with further renewed rises possible from late Saturday with forecast rainfall.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do:

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.

Impacts in your area:

Impacts in your area:
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
  • You may lose services including power, water, sewerage and telephone due to flooding.
  • Heavy rainfall may lead to an increased risk of landslides be aware of fallen earth, rocks, debris or trees.
  • Snakes, spiders and rats may try to find shelter in your home, even if raised.
  • Parks, hiking tracks and campgrounds are closed due to flooding. To find out more go to www.parkweb.vic.gov.au/safety/flood-affected-parks 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 02/12/2023 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Mitchell River downstream of Glenaladale.

MODERATE FLOODING OCCURRING AT BAIRNSDALE FRIDAY AFTERNOON

Rainfall since Wednesday morning across the Mitchell River catchment has resulted in river level rises and areas of flooding. Further rainfall is forecast for the remainder of Friday and into the weekend.

Renewed river level rises may occur over the weekend with the forecast rainfall.

Mitchell River downstream of Glenaladale:

Moderate flooding is occurring along the Mitchell River downstream of Glenaladale.

The Mitchell River at Bairnsdale is currently at 5.94 metres and rising, with moderate flooding. The Mitchell River at Bairnsdale is likely to peak near 6.10 metres overnight Friday into Saturday. Renewed rises are possible with the forecast rain.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do:
  • Farmers should move livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.

Impacts in your area:

Impacts in your area:
  • Lind bridge may be impacted overnight on Friday.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 02/12/2023 01:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This is a Final Minor Flood Warning for Traralgon Creek at Traralgon. 

  • MINOR FLOODING NO LONGER LIKELY AT TRARALGON.

The river level at Traralgon has peaked below the minor flood level and is falling. Further showers and rain is forecast through the weekend and the situation will continue to be monitored.

Traralgon Creek:

Flooding is no longer likely in the Traralgon Creek. The Traralgon Creek at Traralgon is currently at 3.28 metres and falling, below the minor flood level (3.50 m). The Traralgon Creek at Traralgon is likely to remain below the minor flood level (3.50 m).
The threat of flooding is reduced. Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and beware of hazards remaining in the warning area.
What you should do:

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.

If your home or business has been flooded:
  • Check for building damage before you enter.
  • Have all electrical and gas equipment professionally tested before use.
  • Clean and dry out the building as soon as possible.

Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. For emergency assistance from the SES call 132 500.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Damage to roads and buildings caused by flooding may still exist in your area. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

This will be the last warning for this flood. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Thomson River Cowwar Weir to Wandocka
properties.webBody:
This Major Flood Warning is being issued for Thomson River Cowwar Weir to Wandocka.

MAJOR FLOODING STEADY AT WANDOCKA

Rainfall during the week across the Thomson River catchment has resulted in some strong river level rises. Further rainfall is forecast across the Thomson River catchment for the remainder of Friday and into the weekend which may cause renewed river level rises.

The situation is being closely monitored, and warnings will be updated as necessary.

Thomson River Cowwarr Weir to Wandocka:

Major flooding is continuing along the Thomson River Cowwarr Weir to Wandocka.

The Thomson River at Wandocka is currently at 6.74 metres and steady, above the major flood level (6.70 m). The Thomson River at Wandocka is likely to remain around the major flood level (6.70 m) overnight Friday into Saturday. 

The river level may fall below the moderate flood level (6.50 m) Saturday morning, with further renewed rises possible from late Saturday with forecast rainfall.
Move to higher ground. Act now - immediately take actions to protect your life and property.
What you should do: 
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater. 
  • Decide if you will evacuate if it becomes necessary. 
If you choose to leave: 
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding. 
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave. 
If you are travelling: 
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around and find a safe alternative route. 
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.   
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave: 
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated. 
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow. 
Stay informed - listen to emergency broadcasters and monitor warnings.
Impacts in your area: 
  • For information on road closures go to traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
  • Parks, hiking tracks and campgrounds are closed due to flooding. To find out more go to www.parkweb.vic.gov.au/safety/flood-affected-parks.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

The next update is expected by 02/12/2023 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Mitchell River to Glenaladale.

MINOR FLOODING CONTINUING AT GLENALADALE

Rainfall since Wednesday morning across the Mitchell River catchment has resulted in river level rises and areas of flooding. Further rainfall is forecast for the remainder of Friday and into the weekend.

Renewed river level rises may occur over the weekend with the forecast rainfall.

Mitchell River to Glenaladale:

Minor flooding is continuing along the Mitchell River at Glenaladale. Renewed rises are possible with the forecast rain.

The Mitchell River at Glenaladale peaked at around 4.19 metres during Friday afternoon. The river level is currently at 4.15 metres and falling, with minor flooding. The Mitchell River at Glenaladale is expected to remain above the minor flood level (3.00 m) during Friday and into Saturday, with renewed rises possible.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
Impacts in your area: 
  • Parks, hiking tracks and campgrounds are closed due to flooding. To find out more go to www.parkweb.vic.gov.au/safety/flood-affected-parks.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 02/12/2023 01:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • For road closure information go to www.traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au or phone 13 11 70.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
ADVICE - RIVERINE FLOOD - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Mitchell River to Glenaladale
Issue Date: Friday 01 December 2023, 06:56 pm
Next Update: Saturday 02 December 2023, 01:30 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/31250/moreinfo

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Mitchell River to Glenaladale.

MINOR FLOODING CONTINUING AT GLENALADALE

Rainfall since Wednesday morning across the Mitchell River catchment has resulted in river level rises and areas of flooding. Further rainfall is forecast for the remainder of Friday and into the weekend.

Renewed river level rises may occur over the weekend with the forecast rainfall. 

Mitchell River to Glenaladale:

Minor flooding is continuing along the Mitchell River at Glenaladale. Renewed rises are possible with the forecast rain.

The Mitchell River at Glenaladale peaked at around 4.19 metres during Friday afternoon. The river level is currently at 4.15 metres and falling, with minor flooding. The Mitchell River at Glenaladale is expected to remain above the minor flood level (3.00 m) during Friday and into Saturday, with renewed rises possible. 

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Thomson River downstream of Wandocka.

MODERATE FLOODING LIKELY AT SALE OVERNIGHT FRIDAY INTO SATURDAY

Rainfall during the week across the Thomson River catchment has resulted in some strong river level rises. Further rainfall is forecast across the Thomson River catchment for the remainder of Friday and into the weekend which may cause renewed river level rises.

The situation is being closely monitored, and warnings will be updated as necessary.

Thomson River downstream of Wandocka:
Moderate flooding is occurring along the Thomson River downstream of Wandocka.

The Thomson River at Sale Wharf is currently at 3.05 metres just above the moderate flood level (3.00 metres) and rising. 

The Thomson River at Sale Wharf may peak near 3.70 metres overnight Friday into Saturday, with moderate flooding.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do:
  • Farmers should move livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Sandbags will be available from the Sale SES unit in Union Street on Saturday morning between 0930 and 1200.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.

Impacts in your area:

Impacts in your area:
  • Parks, hiking tracks and campgrounds are closed due to flooding. To find out more go to www.parkweb.vic.gov.au/safety/flood-affected-parks.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 02/12/2023 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Murchison East.

  • There is a hay shed fire on Douglas Road. 
  • The fire is under control.
  • Smoke will be visible from nearby roads and communities. 
There is currently no threat to the community, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond. 
  • If you are sensitive to smoke or you live with someone who is sensitive to smoke, you should close windows and doors. Turn off heating and cooling systems.
  • To prevent the smell of smoke entering your home or business, close windows and doors.  
Impacts in your area: 
  • Emergency services will remain in the area.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 02/12/2023 04:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 

  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:

  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Bemm River.

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Friday, rainfall totals of 50-120 mm were recorded across the Cann, Genoa and Bemm River catchments. Further showers are forecast in East Gippsland during the remainder of Friday and into the weekend.

Bemm River:

River levels are easing in the Bemm River catchment for the remainder of Friday and into the weekend with renewed rises possible due to forecast rainfall.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 02/12/2023 11:00 am or as the situation changes.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge.

MODERATE FLOODING POSSIBLE AT D/S BASIN CREEK, JARRAHMOND AND ORBOST DURING SATURDAY

Rainfall over the last few days has caused river level rises and flooding in the Snowy River Catchment. Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the weekend, which will cause renewed river level rises and may exacerbate flood levels.

Moderate flooding may occur in the Snowy River at D/S Basin Creek, Jarrahmond and Orbost during Saturday.

River levels are continuing to ease in the Bombala River and Buchan River.

The situation will continue to be closely monitored.

Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge:

Moderate flooding may occur along the Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge.

The Snowy River D/S Basin Ck is currently at 4.57 metres and rising, with minor flooding. A peak around the moderate flood level (5.50 m) may occur in the Snowy River D/S Basin Ck Saturday morning.

The Snowy River at Jarrahmond is currently at 5.50 metres and steady, with minor flooding. The Snowy River at Jarrahmond may reach the moderate flood level (6.20 m) Saturday morning, with further rises during the afternoon.

The Snowy River at Orbost is currently at 5.63 metres and steady, with minor flooding. The Snowy River at Orbost may reach the moderate flood level (6.00 m) Saturday evening.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do:
  • Farmers should move livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.

Impacts in your area:

Impacts in your area:
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
  • Parks, hiking tracks and campgrounds are closed due to flooding. To find out more go to www.parkweb.vic.gov.au/safety/flood-affected-parks.
  • Heavy rainfall may lead to an increased risk of landslides be aware of fallen earth, rocks, debris or trees.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 02/12/2023 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Tambo River.

MINOR FLOODING EASING AT D/S RAMROD CREEK

Heavy rainfall across the Tambo River catchment over the last few days has resulted in minor flooding at D/S Ramrod Creek.

Further rainfall is expected during Friday and over the weekend which may lead to renewed river level rises.

Tambo River:

Minor flooding may occur along the Tambo River.

The Tambo River D/S Ramrod Creek peaked at 4.95 metres (minor flooding) around 04:30 am Friday 01December and is currently at 4.39 metres and falling. 

The Tambo River D/S Ramrod Creek is likely to fall below the minor flood level (4.10 m) Friday afternoon.

  • This is an update, replacing the Advice message issued at 1:22 PM on 1 December 2023.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 02/12/2023 03:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • For road closure information go to www.traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au or phone 13 11 70.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This is a Final Minor Flood Warning for Cann River. 

  • Flooding has eased along the Cann River.
  • The Cann River (West) at Weeragua peaked at 3.18 metres around 08:00 pm Thursday 30 November with minor flooding. The river level is currently at 2.52 metres and falling, below the minor flood level (3.0 m). The Cann River (West) at Weeragua is expected to remain below the minor flood level (3.00 m) for the remainder of Friday and into Saturday. Renewed rises are possible due to forecast rainfall over the weekend.
  • The Cann River (East) at Chandlers Creek peaked at 2.20 metres around 04:00 pm Thursday 30 November with minor flooding. The river level is currently at 1.24 metres and steady, below the minor flood level (2.0m). The Cann River (East) at Chandlers Creek is expected to remain below the minor flood level (2.00 m)for the remainder of Friday and into Saturday. Renewed rises are possible due to forecast rainfall over the weekend
The threat of flooding is reduced. Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and beware of hazards remaining in the warning area.
What you should do:

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Drive slowly, obey all roadblocks and never drive through floodwaters.
  • If cleaning after damage has occurred, protect your health and safety. Wear strong boots, gloves and protective clothing and wash your hands and clothes regularly.
  • Be aware of driving hazards, such as mud, debris, damaged roads and fallen trees.
  • Floodwater is toxic. If properties have been impacted by flood water, please consider the following: - Contaminated sandbags must be disposed of carefully and never reused. - It is important for your health to dispose of, or properly clean, contaminated items to stay safe from dangerous mould, chemicals, and biologic hazards in floodwater. -Drinking water may be contaminated, so seek out information to confirm it

If your home or business has been flooded:
  • Check for building damage before you enter.
  • Have all electrical and gas equipment professionally tested before use.
  • Clean and dry out the building as soon as possible.

Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. For emergency assistance from the SES call 132 500.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Damage to roads and buildings caused by flooding may still exist in your area. 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
  • Heavy rainfall may lead to an increased risk of landslides be aware of fallen earth, rocks, debris or trees.
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

This will be the last warning for this flood. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Macalister River downstream of Lake Glenmaggie.
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Macalister River downstream of Lake Glenmaggie.

MODERATE FLOODING CONTINUING DOWNSTREAM OF LAKE GLENMAGGIE

Rainfall from Wednesday and into Friday has caused river level rises in the Macalister River catchment. Further showers are forecast across the Macalister River catchment for the remainder of Friday and into the weekend. This situation is being closely monitored, and warnings will be updated as necessary.

Macalister River downstream of Lake Glenmaggie:

Moderate flooding is continuing downstream of Lake Glenmaggie with current dam releases during Friday afternoon.

The Macalister River D/S Lake Glenmaggie is currently at 4.79 metres and steady, with moderate flooding. The Macalister River D/S Lake Glenmaggie is likely to remain above the moderate flood level (4.30 m) for the remainder of Friday and overnight into Saturday.

Inflows into Lake Glenmaggie have slowed. This means that releases from Lake Glenmaggie are being managed to ensure impacts downstream are minimised especially to local levees. Any major increases will be communicated via the Emergency Vic app and website if required.

For specific information on in/out-flows please go to the Southern Rural Waters website: www.srw.com.au/water-and-storage/warnings/floods 
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do:
  • Farmers should move livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.

Impacts in your area:

Impacts in your area:
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
For specific information on in/out-flows please go to the Southern Rural Waters website
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 02/12/2023 11:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Snowy River to Mckillops Bridge.

Rainfall over the last few days has caused river level rises and flooding in the Snowy River Catchment. Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the weekend, which will cause renewed river level rises and may exacerbate flood levels.

Moderate flooding may occur in the Snowy River at D/S Basin Creek, Jarrahmond and Orbost during Saturday.

River levels are continuing to ease in the Bombala River and Buchan River.

The situation will continue to be closely monitored.

Snowy River to McKillops Bridge:

Minor flooding is occurring along the Snowy River to McKillops Bridge.

The McKillops Bridge river station is currently underestimating the river level. The river level is expected to be above the minor flood level (2.50 m) and rising. A minor peak is likely in the Snowy River at McKillops Bridge overnight Friday into Saturday.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
Impacts in your area: 
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers.
  • Parks, hiking tracks and campgrounds are closed due to flooding. To find out more go to www.parkweb.vic.gov.au/safety/flood-affected-parks.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 02/12/2023 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • For road closure information go to www.traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au or phone 13 11 70.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

ADVICE - RIVERINE FLOOD - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Snowy River to McKillops Bridge
Issue Date: Friday 01 December 2023, 05:14 pm
Next Update: Saturday 02 December 2023, 12:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/31245/moreinfo

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Snowy River to Mckillops Bridge.

Rainfall over the last few days has caused river level rises and flooding in the Snowy River Catchment. Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the weekend, which will cause renewed river level rises and may exacerbate flood levels.

Moderate flooding may occur in the Snowy River at D/S Basin Creek, Jarrahmond and Orbost during Saturday.

River levels are continuing to ease in the Bombala River and Buchan River.

The situation will continue to be closely monitored. 

Snowy River to McKillops Bridge:

Minor flooding is occurring along the Snowy River to McKillops Bridge.

The McKillops Bridge river station is currently underestimating the river level. The river level is expected to be above the minor flood level (2.50 m) and rising. A minor peak is likely in the Snowy River at McKillops Bridge overnight Friday into Saturday. 

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Major Flood Warning is being issued for Avon River. 

MAJOR FLOODING EASING AT STRATFORD DURING FRIDAY EVENING

River levels along the Avon River are falling after a major flood peak at Stratford Friday morning.

Rainfall is forecast to continue for the remainder of Friday and into the weekend which may see renewed river level rises. 

The situation will continue to be closely monitored

Avon River:

Major flooding is occurring along the Avon River.

The Avon River at Stratford peaked at 7.26 metres around 8:30 am Friday and is currently at 6.53 metres and falling, above the major flood level (6.50 m). The Avon River at Stratford is expected to fall below the major flood level (6.50 m) Friday evening. The river level may fall below the moderate flood level (6.00 m)overnight Friday into Saturday

This is an update, replacing the Watch and Act message issued at 12.48pm. 
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do:

  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.

Impacts in your area:

Impacts in your area:
The following roads may be impacted:
  • Princes Hwy at the railway bridge in Stratford
  • Maffra-Stratford Rd west of Stratford
  • Briagolong-Boisdale Rd east of Boisdale
  • Briagolong-Valencia Creek Rd east of Valencia Creek and west of Marathon Rd Briagolong
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures.
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
  • Parks, hiking tracks and campgrounds are closed due to flooding. To find out more go to www.parkweb.vic.gov.au/safety/flood-affected-parks.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 02/12/2023 02:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Incident Location: Avon River
Issue Date: Friday 01 December 2023, 05:40 pm
Next Update: Saturday 02 December 2023, 02:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/31248/moreinfo

Avon River:

The Avon River at Stratford is expected to fall below the major flood level (6.50 m) Friday evening. The river level may fall below the moderate flood level (6.00 m)overnight Friday into Saturday

        Stay safe - avoid the   flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never   enter floodwater.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Buchan River.

MODERATE FLOODING POSSIBLE AT D/S BASIN CREEK, JARRAHMOND AND ORBOST DURING SATURDAY

  • Rainfall over the last few days has caused river level rises and flooding in the Snowy River Catchment. Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the weekend, which will cause renewed river level rises and may exacerbate flood levels.
  • Moderate flooding may occur in the Snowy River at D/S Basin Creek, Jarrahmond and Orbost during Saturday.
  • River levels are continuing to ease in the Bombala River and Buchan River.
  • The situation will continue to be closely monitored
Buchan River:

  • Minor flooding is occurring along the Buchan River.
  • The Buchan River at Buchan peaked at 3.70 metres around midnight Thursday into Friday and is currently at 3.27 metres and falling, with minor flooding. The Buchan River at Buchan is likely to remain above the minor flood level (2.50 m) overnight Friday into Saturday
This Advice replaces the Watch and Act message issued at 12.08pm. 
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
  • Floodwater is toxic floodwater near fire affected areas may contain ash and debris from recent fires. 
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
  • Parks, hiking tracks and campgrounds are closed due to flooding. To find out more go to www.parkweb.vic.gov.au/safety/flood-affected-parks.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 02/12/2023 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • For road closure information go to www.traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au or phone 13 11 70.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/31246/moreinfo
